cooking_tips.tips: Before cooking, soak 4 to 12 hours with water in the refrigerator. After boiling, drain, glaze and brown at 400 F for 15 minutes.

Cooking times for poultry are for unstuffed birds. Check the internal temperature in the innermost part of the thigh, innermost part of the wing and the thickest part of the breast. Add 15 to 30 minutes for stuffed birds. Stuffed birds are ready when the internal temperature of stuffing reaches 165 F.

Cooking times for poultry are for unstuffed birds. Check the internal temperature in the innermost part of the thigh, innermost part of the wing and the thickest part of the breast. Add 15 to 30 minutes for stuffed birds. Stuffed birds are ready when the internal temperature of stuffing reaches 165 F.
Cooking suggestions are for burgers. Cooking times are per side if grilling

name: Potatoes
pantry_tips: This is the recommended storage method for whole potatoes.
refrigerate_tips: The United States Potato Board notes refrigeration can cause potatoes to darken during cooking and to develop an unpleasantly sweet taste.
freeze_tips: Freezer timeline applies to cooked and mashed potatoes.

name: Tomatoes
pantry_tips: Until Ripe, then 7 days. Ripe is when this item is tender, fully developed and ready to eat. Refrigeration may affect flavor, USDA recommends pantry storage.

name: Barbecue sauce
pantry_tips: Refrigeration ensures that commercial sauces and condiments stay fresh for a longer period of time. Shelf-stable commercial barbecue sauce is safe when stored at room temperature after opening.  Quality, not safety, is the reason the labels on these products suggest that they be refrigerated after opening.

name: Dry gravy mixes
refrigerate_tips: Refrigeration time applies to prepared product.

name: Ketchup, cocktail, or chili sauce
pantry_tips: Refrigeration ensures that commercial sauces and condiments stay fresh for a longer period of time. Shelf-stable commercial ketchup, cocktail sauce, or chili sauce are safe when stored at room temperature after opening.  Quality, not safety, is the reason the labels on these products suggest that they be refrigerated after opening.

name: Canned goods
name_subtitle: Low acid (such as meat, poultry, fish, gravy, stew, soups, beans, carrots, corn, pasta, peas, potatoes, spinach)
pantry_tips: Canned items will be safe to eat well past the ‘use-by’ or ‘best by’ date as long as the can shows no dents, rust, or swelling.
